Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2007 11:11PM acupunc wrote: It is so comforting to hear all of your stories about waiting.  I was diagnosed with DCIS, grade 3, on Sept. 6, following the stereotactic biopsy on Sept. 4.  I then had a PEM scan (PET scan for breasts), which indicated a possible 2nd cancer in an adjacent quadrant of the same (L) breast.  Then my breast surgeon sent me for an MRI this past Monday and I am still waiting for results.  Based on the findings, I may be facing a mastectomy and sentinel node biopsy.  (I tested negative for estrogen receptors.) In the meantime, I scheduled a 2nd opinion with another breast surgeon, but she can't see me till October 11.  I started freaking out, thinking that will be 5 weeks since the original diagnosis, meaning I might not have surgery for another week or so.  But after reading these comments, I am relaxing and realizing that patience is one of the lessons here....and as we used to say in the Sixties, "go with the flow."  (And also be suitably assertive about following up on appts.)  It is amazing how people's vacations delay test results, isn't it???  Good luck, Amy!  We're all in it together.  Donna

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2007 11:20PM acupunc wrote: I was diagnosed on September 6 with DCIS.  My 20-year old son was devastated and I thought it would be helpful to have a RTR volunteer come out and speak with both of us.  I went online, tracked down the local office and called them.  The person I spoke with was like a robot; she insisted that I call the national headquarters and register and then ask for what I wanted.  I did so; the volunteer who took my info promised me that 2 people would return my call -- one to help me alone; the other, for my son and me together.  They were supposed to call earlier this week.  No call back.  Meanwhile, I also found a local Gilda's Club and they have a new members' meeting twice a week.  I'm signed up for next Wed.  Here's hoping they are more helpful!  It is a blessing to discover this online group.  Thank God for other women in cyberspace who touch our lives!
